state.name: VGS=0 VDS=0
state.p: Just as with the semiconductor diode, there is a depletion region across the p-n junction formed between the gate and the channel.
Because the gate is much more heavily doped than the channel, the depletion region extends mainly into the channel.

state.name: VGS=0 VDS=2
state.p: Initially there will be a linear relation between the drain current and the drain-source voltage. This is called the ohmic or linear region.

As VDS increases the depletion region extends further at the drain end of the channel. Being nearer the drain the potential is higher at this end, resulting in a larger reverse bias across the p-n junction.

state.name: VGS=0 VDS=sat
state.p: ID does not increase indefinitely with VDS, and eventually flattens out in the saturation region.
It is not possible for the depletion region to completely constrict the channel because then the drain current would vanish and there would no longer be a higher reverse bias at the drain end.

state.name: VGS=0 VDS=10
state.p: An equilibrium is established and the drain current flattens off.

state.name: VGS=-0,5 VDS=0
state.p: The extent of the depletion region is determined by VGS. As VGS becomes more negative, the depletion region constricts more of the channel, whose resistance increases.

state.name: VGS=-0,5 VDS=2
state.p: Making VGS more negative increases the resistance so the drain current is smaller for the same drain-source voltage.

state.name: VGS=-0,5 VDS=sat
state.p: Saturation is reached with a lower VDS since the more negative VGS means the channel is already more constricted.

state.name: VGS=-0,5 VDS=10
state.p: In the saturation region, the more negative VGS has reduced the width of the channel at the source end. This increases the resistance and lowers the drain current.

state.name: VGS=-1 VDS=0
state.p: The extent of the depletion region is determined by VGS. As VGS becomes more negative, the depletion region constricts more of the channel, whose resistance increases.

state.name: VGS=-1 VDS=2
state.p: Making VGS more negative increases the resistance so the drain current is smaller for the same drain-source voltage.

state.name: VGS=-1 VDS=sat
state.p: Saturation is reached with a lower VDS since the more negative VGS means the channel is already more constricted.

state.name: VGS=-1 VDS=10
state.p: In the saturation region, the more negative VGS has reduced the width of the channel at the source end. This increases the resistance and lowers the drain current.

state.name: VGS=-2 VDS=0
state.p: If VGS is made sufficiently negative, the depletion region completely constricts the channel.
This happens when VGS = VP, the pinch-off voltage.

state.name: VGS=-2 VDS=2
state.p: Once VGS is more negative than the pinch-off voltage, ID remains at zero for all values of VDS. The channel is completely constricted so that no current can flow.

state.name: VGS=-2 VDS=sat
state.p: Once VGS is more negative than the pinch-off voltage, ID remains at zero for all values of VDS. The channel is completely constricted so that no current can flow.

state.name: VGS=-2 VDS=10
state.p: Once VGS is more negative than the pinch-off voltage, ID remains at zero for all values of VDS. The channel is completely constricted so that no current can flow.
